sections.text:
A.1. Other Mars data sets
The more usual interpretation of the northern-latitudes is that they are volcanic; a view substantiated with data from the Mars Global Surveyor Thermal Emission Spectrometer (TES) (Bandfield et al., 2000). How generally this view is applied can be summarised by the following paragraph [from a review of the predecessor of this paper (i.e., Page and Murray, 2006)], regarding the deposits of the Cerberus Formation: “The thermal inertia and spectral data are consistent with a mafic lava flow with a dust coating. So are the GRS compositional data. As are the Earth-based radar data. And theoretical modelling shows that lava could indeed form these features. The entire suite of data collected over the last three decades from Mars is consistent with these being lava surfaces.” A year does not pass without reference to the correct identification of these deposits as ‘the youngest lava flows on Mars’ (e.g., McEwen et al., 1998; McEwen, 1999; Hartmann and Berman, 2000; Hartmann and Neukum, 2001; Fagents et al., 2002; Lanagan and McEwen, 2003; Lanagan, 2004; Wilcox and Hamilton, 2005), yet how many pause to wonder how safe this identification is? Its morphological basis is equivocal, at best: “The platy-ridged material is interpreted to be lava because it is bounded by lobatemargins characteristic of lava flows” (Keszthelyi et al., 2000). While some have questioned this view (e.g., Rice et al., 2002; Williams and Malin, 2004; Murray et al., 2005), its general acceptance generates one of the great extrapolations of modern Mars science: that the planet has experienced flood volcanism, on a scale large enough to resurface large areas of the northern plains, well within the last 1% of its history. As the evidence in the present account is at odds with what is a widely held view, let us consider each of the spectral, thermal inertial and compositional data sets in turn.
Data from the TES describe two broad spectral signatures distributed approximately north–south of the planetary dichotomy: a Surface Type 2 (ST2) that (variously) defines the surface composition of the northern plains as andesitic (Bandfield et al., 2000), or aqueously altered basaltic (Wyatt and McSween, 2002), and a basaltic Surface Type 1 (ST1) in the southern highlands. The susceptibility of the TES to bright surface dust at low latitudes is well documented (Mellon et al., 2000; Wyatt et al., 2004), this globally homogeneous dust layer obscuring the signature of the underlying bedrock from spectral analysis. The Cerberus plains lie within a large, equatorial ‘blind spot,’ clearly visible in published maps of emissivity and thermal inertia (e.g., Jakosky et al., 2000; Ruff and Christensen, 2002; Putzig et al., 2005), and it is this that has allowed the view of these deposits as dust-coated lava flows to be maintained, particularly where windows of igneous composition are apparent within the dust (Wilcox and Hamilton, 2005). Using high-resolution TES data to identify areas of particulate basalt within this ‘dusty’ region, Rogers and Christensen (2003) found the Cerberus plains around 9◦–14◦ N/149◦–162◦ E [Cerberus Fossae and the proximal Athabasca Valles (e.g., Fig. 10)] to have thermal inertia values (∼250 to
>300 J/m2 K s1/2) indicative of particle sizes within the range of silt to coarse sand (200–800 µm). Nowhere were values consistent with bedrock [∼2400 J/m2 K s1/2 (e.g., Jakosky, 1979)].
This large area of low thermal inertia may be consistent with loose surface dust (Mellon et al., 2000), but the higher spatial resolution of the Thermal Emission Imaging System (THEMIS), onboard Mars Odyssey, reveals distinct thermal differences between the plate and inter-plate (i.e., polygonally patterned) regions. This is the case for both day- and night-time infrared observations (Figs. 10a and 10b), the latter a proxy for thermal inertia, and more indicative of intrinsic thermal and material properties (Fergason and Christensen, 2003), so the consistent division of these deposits into platy and polygonal areas tells us something about the different processes that affect them. In the nighttime brightness image (Fig. 10b), plates appear dark (cool) and polygonal areas light (warm), indicating that the plates have lower thermal inertia, relative to their polygonal surroundings, and are composed of, or mantled by, finergrained materials. This thermal variation has been attributed to dust trapping in the inter-plate regions (Keszthelyi et al., 2006), yet these are the areas of highest (relative) thermal inertia: not what would be expected if this were the case. It is known
from thermal studies of terrestrial permafrost that regions of thaw penetration have high thermal inertia [associated with surmounting the 0 ◦C/273 K ‘barrier’ at the triple point (Viterbo et al., 1999)]. In this context, the greater (relative) thermal inertia of the polygonal ground is consistent with freeze–thaw cycling and enhanced volatile-loss in these areas. There is little doubt that the Cerberus region is dusty [or that this is changeable over short timescales (e.g., Geissler, 2005)], but neither the spectral nor the thermal inertial data can be said to indicate that the deposits of the Cerberus plains are lava.
An igneous component to these deposits there may well be (Wilcox and Hamilton, 2005), but that is not the same as saying these are lava flows. Volcanogenic sediment, however, is a different matter. The initial results of a more silicic composition for the younger deposits of the northern plains (ST2) are also interpreted as low-temperature aqueously altered basalts weathered under icy conditions during periods of higher obliquity (Wyatt et al., 2004). The dominantly igneous mineralogy of ST2 and the clear basaltic component from MER Mini-TES in the dark soils at Gusev and Meridiani (Yen et al., 2005) imply only limited aqueous alteration in the northern plains, but deposition of sediment does not always involve water. Tharsis magmatism during the late Amazonian (Fairén et al., 2003; Hynek et al., 2003; Tanaka, 2000) could have supplied volcanic air fall (or tephra) to the Cerberus region, providing nucleation sites for the condensation of atmospheric water vapour in the process. The easily eroded deposits of the Medusae Fossae Formation (MFF) are a prime candidate for such icy air fall, particularly as these directly overlie the Cerberus Formation in southern Elysium Planitia, are the location of the large near-equatorial hydrogen reservoir identified by the GRS-NS (Feldman et al., 2004b), and contain features of subglacial origin (Page, in preparation).
Although the compositional (GRS) data cannot be said to support a volcanic origin for the Cerberus plains (composition does not equal lithology), if ground ice is as abundant as this account suggests, then why is it not visible? The lack of a hydrogen signal here would seem a strong argument against this interpretation, were it not for the expectation that ground ice at this latitude should lie beyond the detection depth of this instrument. The fast- and epithermal-neutron count rates measured by the GRS-NS are usually understood in terms of a two-layer model, suggesting that most WEH at low latitudes is buried below a relatively desiccated layer (e.g., Feldman et al., 2004a). That is, a high-hydrogen (ice-rich) zone below a low-hydrogen (ice-free) soil that thickens equatorward, until the ice is too deep to be detected (Boynton et al., 2002). Ground ice that is in diffusive equilibrium with atmospheric water vapour at midhigh latitudes (Mellon et al., 2004) is in diffusive disequilibrium at near-equatorial latitudes (Feldman et al., 2004b), so the ice table recedes with decreasing latitude (a corollary of this disequilibrium is that ground ice in the Cerberus plain can only be archaic if atmospheric, else subsurface in origin). Yet, a drop in ground ice content away from the poles is not expected from climate models [quite the opposite (e.g., Mischna et al., 2003)], water ice being stable at all latitudes during periods of higher obliquity (Mellon and Jakosky, 1995), or through-
out a global subsurface aquifer (Clifford, 1993). The thickness of the ice-free layer is presumed to exceed 1 m equatorward of ±45◦ (Boynton, W.V., personal communication, 2006), but the instruments of the GRS package are only sensitive to the upper metre of the regolith, so if this is itself desiccated, as would be expected at this low latitude, ice can no longer be detected from orbit (Feldman et al., 2004a). That a hydrogen signal is detected in the Medusae Fossae, at even lower latitude, is not explained, but as the MFF suffers substantial wind erosion (forming yardangs), it seems entirely reasonable that this volatile should be visible.
Basaltic sediment deposited from air fall as a volcanic dust/ice mixture is consistent with patterned ground as ice-rich, even without spectral masking (which would probably show these deposits to be ST2). It is valid for describing the ST2 spectrum (Wyatt and McSween, 2002), and fits with both the regional thermal inertial and spectral data, particularly as TES spectra are thought to represent fine-grained particulate material, rather than bedrock (Christensen et al., 2000). It is similarly compatible with the GRS-NS and radar data, the enhanced backscatter of which is only an indication of surface roughness (Harmon et al., 1992), and not a proxy for lithology. Finally, icy volcanogenic air fall would provide the required global-scale formation mechanism for ST2 [to account for local occurrences of Type 2 material in the southern highlands (Bandfield, 2002; Rogers and Christensen, 2003; Wyatt et al., 2004)], without the attendant problems of creating vast amounts of andesite, or aqueously altered basalt, in the absence of magmatic or surface water [see Wyatt and McSween (2003) and Hamilton et al. (2003) for discussion].
By contrast, and occupying the mineralogical middle ground between the ‘dry silicic’ and ‘aqueous mafic’ interpretations of TES data, the latest near-infrared hyperspectral imagery from the OMEGA instrument onboard Mars Express shows primary iron-bearing igneous constituents, such as olivine and pyroxene, to be weak or absent in the northern plains (ST2), enrichment in hydrated phases also lacking (Mustard et al., 2005; Bibring et al., 2006). Wide areas of the northern lowlands with no mafic signature are inconsistent with ‘plains-style’ volcanism, but both observations are uniform with the cold-climate, secondary origin advanced here. The deposits of the Cerberus Formation are the ‘younger channel and flood-plain materials,’ units Ach and Achp, of Scott and Tanaka (1986) and Tanaka et al. (1992). The latest geological mapping of the northern plains (Tanaka et al., 2005) now maps these same deposits as a large field of lava flows (the ‘Cerberus Fossae 3’ unit, AEc3), citing reported evidence of volcanic origin (i.e., Keszthelyi et al., 2000; Plescia, 2003; Lanagan, 2004). From the periglacial perspective of this account, the original mapping of these deposits (as alluvial) accords better with the observed geomorphological and stratigraphical relationships.
A.2. Consilience and hypothesis testing
The nature of low latitude patterned grounds in the Cerberus plains is a question that has brought every Mars data set into play, and if much of these data have been interpreted as con-
sistent with a volcanic origin, as inferred from morphology (Plescia, 1990), lava flow modelling (Keszthelyi et al., 2000), and radar data (Harmon et al., 1992), they are not exclusively so. Baker (2001), in outlining the inductive process of Whewell (1840), states that: “Ultimately in geomorphological investigation, one chooses the working hypothesis that is most fruitful with regard to connection to other lines of scientific inquiry, while still providing consistency and coherence in explaining the whole complex of available observations.” Inductive reasoning yields one major type of conclusion: consilience, where seemingly unrelated observations can be made to cohere in one (and only one) possible way. This single co-ordinating explanation for the joint existence of otherwise incoherent observations is the distinctive feature of consilience; it does not constitute a formal proof, but a test of the validity of a working hypothesis. The hypothesis in the present account is that the plains-forming deposits of the Cerberus Formation are periglacial, based on form and context of landforms relative to the known terrestrial environment. This analogy leads to a second hypothesis (partially a product of the first), that polygonal ground in this region is secondary; an (expected) consequence of periglaciation that should itself experience cyclical degradation and reaggradation. Unlike the first hypothesis, this is a definite claim that, true or false, can be tested by stratigraphical superposition. In every described instance, i.e., Figs. 2, 6 and 7, this test shows that polygonal ground, and other periglacial features such as pingos postdate the substrate in which they occur.
It is axiomatic in geology that ‘if A crosscuts B, then A must be younger than B’—a methodological prerequisite on which much geological reasoning depends. This is why impact craters (the ‘B’ of this example) were used to test the secondary arguments in this account, as they are the single surface landform that can be said with complete confidence to be post-depositional. Either the features that superpose impact craters in the Cerberus plains are formed after impact, or our understanding of the way in which hypervelocity impact craters form (e.g., Shoemaker, 1963; Maxwell, 1977; Melosh, 1989) is incorrect. The principles of superposition do not necessitate such a conclusion, but when expressed by multiple and varied examples over a wide geographical area, they do predict a high probability of it being true. Geological formations and the landforms they contain are bound by these principles; if our theories do not make stratigraphical sense, then they cannot be correct.
Planetary geology must frequently work without the most fundamental unit of geological information: lithology. If we are to have confidence in the geoscientific validity of inferences drawn from planetary image data, then such formational and temporal constraints as superposition offers should be used to test initial hypotheses. If not, the danger is that the system of multiple working hypotheses is displaced by one of the ‘ruling theory’ (Chamberlin, 1897). This is nowhere clearer than in the Cerberus plains where lava flow modelling, radar data, crater counts, young meteorite ages and formative models of associated landforms are all taken to confirm the general theory of plains-forming volcanism without producing any further geological evidence for it. Where ‘hard’ geological evidence does
exist—the basaltic shergottite meteorites—it lacks provenance, and has no more than an implied connection to the Cerberus region. By adopting this general theory as an unproblematic premise for further inquiry, what began as a geomorphological interpretation has become established, assuming the status of paradigm alluded to earlier, with such deposits now used as the basis for testing other theories, forming “. . . a perfect surface for recording the production function diameter distribution of impact craters,” and “. . . a test of isochron shape” (Hartmann and Neukum, 2001). The production functions on such ‘perfect’ surfaces reflect an ideal size–frequency distribution of craterforming projectiles before changes due to degradational and obliterative processes (Ivanov, 2001; Ivanov et al., 2002), so the distinction between primary and secondary terrains could not be more significant.
These production functions are based on an assumption that objects striking Mars have the same size–frequency distribution as those that cratered the Moon, and are dominated by primary impacts (Neukum et al., 2001; Hartmann and Neukum, 2001). To this must be added a further assumption: that the substrate against which the age isochrons are tested has been correctly identified (as lava). This last assumption is almost universally accepted, and is the mainspring of martian impact crater chronology, yet in the case of the Cerberus plains, it is also the one with the least empirical support. Differences in the frequency and statistics of impact craters on surfaces in this region that should be approximately the same age have been ascribed to an incomplete understanding of the small-crater production functions (Plescia, 2005; McEwen, 2006). However, crater chronology is only as good as the lithological assumptions that are its basis. Would successive refinements of isochron shape (see Hartmann, 1999, 2005; Berman and Hartmann, 2002) largely to reconcile flattening of the production function for small-craters in this region (Hartmann and Berman, 2000; Hartmann and Neukum, 2001; Berman and Hartmann, 2002; Burr et al., 2002a; McEwen, 2003; McEwen et al., 2005) have occurred if the deposits of the Cerberus plains were really the pristine young lava flows they are thought to be? On the basis of the degradation visible in Figs. 2–8, it is difficult to imagine deposits less suited to preserve a production population of impact craters (Hartmann and Neukum, 2001), act as an isochronological reference (Hartmann, 2005), or assess the relative contributions of primary and secondary impacts to the martian cratering record (McEwen et al., 2005; Barlow, 2006). From their earliest modelling onwards, the condition that such theoretical emphasis requires that hypotheses be falsifiable (Popper, 1959) was never applied to these deposits, for there was never any question that they were anything other than lavas (see Keszthelyi et al., 2000, 2004, 2006), and what should have been a hypothesis to be tested became merely a proposition to be confirmed. An un-testable hypothesis is not an effective working hypothesis (e.g., Zimbelman, 2001), so let us say that the volcanic model, to be correct, led to one observable consequence for future study: that its surface landforms, being the product of emplacement and lithification of lava flows, should all be demonstrably primary in origin. They are not. The model is rejected, and something new has been
learned about these deposits, if only that the number of viable working hypotheses can be reduced.

abstractText: Outside polar latitudes, features corresponding to surface thaw have yet to be identified on Mars. The youthful gully landforms observed at mid-high latitude [Malin, M., Edgett, K., 2000. Science 288, 2330–2335] are the nearest candidate, but the source (and nature) of the gully carving agent remains controversial [e.g., Musselwhite, D.S., Swindle, T.D., Lunine, J.I., 2001. Geophys. Res. Lett. 28, 1283–1285; Mellon, M.T., Phillips, R.J., 2001. J. Geophys. Res. 106, 1–15; Knauth, L.P., Burt, D.M., 2002. Icarus 158, 267–271; Costard, F., Forget, F., Mangold, N., Peulvast, J.P., 2002. Science 295, 110–113; Christensen, P.R., 2003. Nature 422, 45–48; Treiman, A.H., 2003. J. Geophys. Res. 108]. At higher obliquity than the present epoch, near-surface ground ice should be present globally [Mellon, M.T., Jakosky, B.M., 1995. J. Geophys. Res. 100 (E6), 11781–11799], populated by condensation of atmospheric water vapour in the top few metres of the regolith, or emplaced as dusty ice sheets reaching down towards the equator. The latitudinal restriction of these gullies to regions poleward of ±30◦ appears to argue against a thaw component to their formation—since ground ice is present and stable at all latitudes at high obliquity, the current (low) obliquity regime should result in ground ice thaw at low latitudes, where insolation and daytime temperatures are currently greatest, and this is not observed. A previously undescribed meltwater sequence in the Cerberus plains, at 20◦ N/187◦ E, shows that comparable, but much more continuous, and mappable melting and surface runoff have occurred in the geologically recent past at near-equatorial latitudes on Mars. Polygonal ground in the Cerberus plains is seen by the Mars Global Surveyor Mars Orbiter Camera (MOC) to suffer sequential, regional-scale volatile-loss consistent with thaw of near-surface ground ice under periglacial conditions. This degradation is continuously sampled by a single MOC strip, showing an icy landscape undergoing thaw modification and collapse, and may form the first evidence of equatorial wet-based glaciation during late Amazonian time, with indications of melting within the last million years. The dissolution and re-formation of polygonal ground links this landform to freeze–thaw processes, providing the conclusion to a question that has been the subject of debate for three decades—whether Mars’ polygonal grounds require ice to form—and a consistent explanation for the fate of the water that carved the great outflow channels, much of which may still reside as ground ice in the regolith. This thaw occurs in the Cerberus Formation; deposits that are considered to be magmatic in origin, and the type formation for late-stage, “plains-style” volcanism on Mars [Keszthelyi, L., McEwen, A.S., Thordarson T., 2000. J. Geophys. Res. 105, 15027–15049]. By superposing large numbers of small impact craters, polygonal ground in the Cerberus plains sustains previous suggestions of a non-magmatic origin for this and other landforms in the region [Page, D.P., Murray, J.B., 2006. Icarus 183, 46–54]. Together, these periglacial landforms document evidence of climate change much younger than is currently recognised by crater counts, with important implications for age constraints on young surfaces and absolute age determinations by this method. It is tentatively suggested that this melting may be occurring today, with a striking correspondence between permafrost thaw in the Cerberus plains, the high atmospheric methane flux currently observed over this region [Mumma, M.J., Novak, R.E., DiSanti, M.A., Bonev, B.P., Dello Russo, N., 2004. Bull. Am. Astron. Soc. 36, 1127; Krasnopolsky, V.A., Maillard, J.P., Owen, T.C., 2004. Icarus 172, 537–547; Formisano, V., Atreya, S., Encrenaz, T., Ignatiev, N., Giuranna, M., 2004. Science 306, 1758–1761], and the only latitude zone on Mars—equatorward of 30◦ N—where melting of ground ice is thought possible in the current climate [Haberle, R.M., McKay, C.P., Schaeffer, J., Cabrol, N.A., Grin, E.A., Zent, A.P., Quinn, R., 2001. J. Geophys. Res. 106 (E10), 23317–23326; Lobitz, B., Wood, B.L., Averner, M.M., McKay, C.P., 2001. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. 98, 2132–2137]. Low-latitude polygonal ground as transient, and hydrologically active over wide areas transforms our understanding of the recent climatic evolution of Mars, supporting models of atmospheric water-ice migration [Mischna, M., Richardson, M.I., Wilson, R.J., McCleese, D.J., 2003. J. Geophys. Res. 108 (E6). 5062], complex, volatile stratigraphies [Clifford, S.M., Parker, T.J., 2001. Icarus 154, 40– 79], and hypothesised, geologically recent ‘ice ages’ [Head, J.W., Mustard, J.F., Kreslavsky, M.A., Milliken, R.E., Marchant, D.R., 2003. Nature 426, 797–802]. The temporal coincidence of glacial epochs on the Earth and Mars during the Quaternary and latest Amazonian would suggest a coupled system linking both [Sagan, C., Young, A.T., 1973.
